byline.contributor: Michael S. Schmidt reported from Washington, and Salman Masood from Multan, Pakistan. Matt Apuzzo contributed reporting from Washington, Declan Walsh from Cairo and Adam Nagourney from San Bernardino, Calif.
byline.original: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and SALMAN MASOOD

abstract: Federal law enforcement officials say Syed Rizwan Farook may have planned attack as early as in 2012 and that he and his wife Tashfeen Malik discussed jihad and martyrdom in 2013; timeline suggests couple considered terrorist acts like their massacre in San Bernardino, Calif, before Islamic State group rose to prominence; revelations also raise questions about vetting process that allowed Malik entry to United States.
lead_paragraph: New information suggests that Syed Rizwan Farook and his wife, Tashfeen Malik, were considering violent action even before the Islamic State rose to prominence.

headline.main: San Bernardino Couple Spoke of Attacks in 2013, F.B.I. Says
headline.print_headline: Attacker’s Plots May Have Begun as Early As 2012

snippet: New information suggests that Syed Rizwan Farook and his wife, Tashfeen Malik, were considering violent action even before the Islamic State rose to prominence.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
